The population of this ward at the [[United Kingdom Census 2011|2011 census]] was 16,141.{{cite web|url=http://www.neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=7&b=13689194&c=Ancoats+and+Clayton&d=14&e=62&g=6342302&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&m=0&r=1&s=1451917364422&enc=1|title= City of Manchester ward population 2011 | website = neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk | publisher = [[Gov.uk]]|accessdate=4 January 2016}} It includes the [[Ancoats]] and [[Clayton, Manchester|Clayton]] districts and part of the [[Northern Quarter (Manchester)|Northern Quarter]]. Under boundary changes by the [[Local Government Boundary Commission for England]] (LGBCE) the ward was abolished and replaced with the new electoral ward [[Ancoats and Beswick (ward)|Ancoats and Beswick]] from May 2018.{{cite book | last = LGBCE | author-link = Local Government Boundary Commission for England | title = Final recommendations on the new electoral arrangements for Manchester 38:55 (intended running time without commercials, 24:05 aired during initial broadcast)

28 August 2008 (repackaged special) | related = ''[[Australia's Funniest Home Videos]]'' }} '''''Australia's Naughtiest Home Videos''''' is an Australian television comedy programme which was broadcast on [[Nine Network]] on 4 September 1992. It was a one-off special spin-off of ''[[Australia's Funniest Home Video Show]]'', depicting videos of sexual situations and other sexually explicit content. The programme was notably taken off the air partway through the broadcast of its [[List of television series canceled after one episode|first and only episode]] on the order of network owner [[Kerry Packer]]. == Background == ''Australia's Funniest Home Video Show'' premiered in 1990, and was similar in concept to the 1989 American special (and later series) ''[[America's Funniest Home Videos]]:'' viewers would send in amateur-shot videos that were unintentionally humorous, and the video deemed the "funniest" by the studio audience was awarded a prize at the end of the show. The [[Television producer|producers]] often received racy or risqué videos that couldn't be included into the programme due to its family-friendly nature, and since the show's policy stated that videos sent in by viewers couldn't be sent back, videos that didn't make it to the program were still kept by the [[Television station|station]].{{cite news|last=Casey|first=Marcus|title=The moment Kerry Packer blew his stack |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/the-moment-kerry-packer-blew-his-stack/story-e6frf0a0-1111117239870|accessdate=30 December 2010|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=20 August 2008}} The producers decided to compile these videos into a one-off special aimed at an adult audience. It differed from ''Australia's Funniest Home Video Show'' in more than just the content of the videos. It had a different opening, a modified version of the ''Australia's Funniest Home Video Show'''s theme song, and a slightly modified set. It was hosted by Australian radio personality [[Doug Mulray]]. Due to the difference in content, the show aired at 8:30 PM and was preceded by a short message warning viewers of the show's content, and informing them that it was a one-off special that was different from ''Australia's Funniest Home Video Show''. == Content == [[File:Naughtyvideosscreenshot.png|thumb|A child grabbing a [[kangaroo's scrotum]] in one of the videos featured in the special.]] The show followed the same structure of ''Australia's Funniest Home Video Show'', in which the videos were shown in short blocks, interspersed with humorous monologues written and delivered by Mulray. Mulray often poked fun at the content of the videos, which he described as "The most sensational collection of home videos since [[Rodney King#Incident|Rodney King nicked out for a pizza recently]]." Mulray also did humorous voice overs as the videos were shown, similar to Lisa Patrick's on ''Australia's Funniest Home Video Show''. The content of the videos included shots of animal [[genitalia]], humans or animals humorously engaging in [[sexual intercourse]], people who get accidentally and humorously [[disrobe]]d, and other situations that often relied on [[Ribaldry|ribald]] humour, including a child grabbing a [[kangaroo]]'s testicles, a man lifting a [[barbell]] with his penis, a man getting his head squeezed between an [[Exotic dancer|erotic dancer]]'s large breasts, an elderly woman removing an envelope from a stripper's undergarments with her [[dentures]], two people running into water with flaming pieces of [[toilet paper]] hanging from their [[buttocks]], and two people filmed having sex in the middle of a park. == Cancellation == {{quote box |width=30em | bgcolor=transparent |align=left|quote=We apologise for this interruption. Unfortunately, a technical problem prevents us continuing our scheduled programme for the moment. In the meantime, we bring you a brief, alternative programme.|salign=right |source=—An announcement made after the show was pulled and just before a rerun of ''Cheers'' aired.}} [[Kerry Packer]], the owner of the [[Nine Network]] at the time, was informed of the show's content by friends while having dinner. He tuned in to watch the show, which was being transmitted on [[TCN]]-9, and was so offended by its content that he phoned the studio operators and angrily shouted, "Get that shit off the air!" Within minutes, [[List of television series canceled after one episode|the series was pulled]].{{Cite web|url=http://bulletin.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=141718|title=Worst of TV|accessdate =14 November 2007|publisher=NineMSN|work=The Bulletin |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110130901/http://bulletin.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=141718 |archivedate=10 January 2008}} After the break, the Nine Network announced that it failed to continue airing the show, purportedly due to technical difficulties, and aired reruns of the American sitcom ''[[Cheers]]'' immediately afterwards to fill in the remaining airtime. In 2008, Bert Newton justified the broadcast explanation: "It's ''technically'' very ''difficult'' to keep a show on air with Mr. Packer on the phone, yelling at you."{{cn|date=September 2018}} Although the same bumper and announcement interrupted the show during every broadcast across Australia, it occurred in different parts of the programme depending on the area it was airing in, due to time differences: In the eastern states, the station simply started airing an episode of ''Cheers'' after a scheduled commercial break, but in other areas, the last part of the show broadcast was of Mulray giving a monologue about "[[bosoms]]" or the aforementioned clip of a child grabbing a kangaroo's scrotum. The show was cancelled before it was scheduled to air in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], and thus its Nine Network affiliate showed a brief message mentioning that the special wouldn't be aired before beginning an episode of ''Cheers''. Despite Packer's objections to the series' content, it was popular among viewers. The special was recorded to a record studio audience. After the announcement, Nine reportedly received "thousands" of phone calls from viewers, with 65 percent of callers upset with the programme being pulled,{{Cite web|url=http://www.ebroadcast.com.au/enews/nine/AUSTRALIA-S-NAUGHTIEST-HOME-VIDEOS---THURSDAY-AUGUST-28-AT-8-30PM-ON-NINE-200808.html|title=Nine Press Release|accessdate=20 August 2008|publisher=eBroadcast|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080823070329/http://www.ebroadcast.com.au/enews/nine/AUSTRALIA-S-NAUGHTIEST-HOME-VIDEOS---THURSDAY-AUGUST-28-AT-8-30PM-ON-NINE-200808.html|archivedate=23 August 2008|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} in contrast to the 60 callers who called in during the show's broadcast, complaining about the show. Viewers were generally bewildered by the sudden interruption and the cut to ''Cheers'', not knowing about the show's cancellation until it was widely reported by the Australian media outlets the next day. The day after the special aired, a furious Packer showed up at Nine's headquarters and held meetings in which he loudly berated Nine's managers and censors, referring to the program as "disgusting and offensive shit." After these meetings, Mulray and many of the staff who were involved with the creation of the special were fired, with Mulray being banned for life from Channel Nine. On his radio show the next day, Mulray commented, "I am the first man in Australian history to be pulled off by Kerry Packer." Mulray returned to Nine to be a judge on the 2005 series ''[[StarStruck (2005 TV series)|StarStruck]]'' shortly after Packer's death on December 26 of that year. == Rebroadcast == In 2008, a full copy of the show was located by Nine's head of factual television. It was aired in its entirety at 8:30 PM on 28 August 2008, one week short of sixteen years after the original special, and at the same time. Promoted as "the show Kerry Packer didn't want you to see", it featured commentary from [[Bert Newton]]; Packer had died in December 2005, and Mulray refused Nine's request to host the special.{{Cite news|date=30 August 2008 |url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,24261915-5001030,00.html |title=Kerry wouldn't have aired 's&#t' |accessdate=31 August 2008 |publisher=[[News Limited]] |work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] |first=Mal |last=Holland |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918094914/http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0%2C22049%2C24261915-5001030%2C00.html |archivedate=18 September 2008 |deadurl=no }} The special was interrupted by the Channel Nine bumper and "technical difficulties" announcement 36 minutes in, cutting to the ''Cheers'' opening credits before resuming to a monologue by Newton, and the latter part of the special that never aired. The re-airing was censored, with portions of Mulray's monologues (including jibes about "fat kids") being cut from the special as they were deemed to be "no longer acceptable". == See also == * ''[[Turn-On]]'', an American TV series that was also pulled from broadcast during its first and only episode. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} [[Category:Nine Network shows]] [[Category:1992 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:1992 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:1990s Australian television series]] [[Category:Australian comedy television series]] [[Category:Television shows set in Sydney]] [[Category:Television controversies]] [[Category:Video clip television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Parodies]] [[Category:Television series canceled after one episode]]

revision.text: {{Italic title}} '''''Candle Cove''''' is a [[creepypasta]] online horror story written by webcartoonist and author [[Kris Straub]] in 2009.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PP_OCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT636&dq=%22Candle+Cove%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjo5YWM1bbOAhVS9GMKHQliCUEQ6AEIJjAC#v=onepage&q=%22Candle%20Cove%22&f=false|title=The Ashgate Research Companion to Paranormal Cultures|last=Jenzen|first=Olu|date=2016-03-23|publisher=Routledge|year=|isbn=9781317042181|location=|pages=|language=en|via=}} The story centers on a fictional television series, also titled Candle Cove, that could only be viewed by a small group of people, predominantly children, who later recall the disturbing show on a web forum.{{Cite web|url=http://www.crushable.com/2011/06/25/entertainment/creepy-things-that-seem-real-but-arent-candle-cove/|title=Creepy Things That Seem Real But Aren’t: Candle Cove|last=Peters|first=Lucia|date=|website=Crushable|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-10}} Straub has stated that he was inspired to write the creepypasta after reading "Area 36-Year-Old Still Has Occasional ''[[Lidsville]]'' Nightmare", an article published via the satirical news outlet ''[[The Onion]]''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.blumhouse.com/2016/08/25/creepypasta-revisiting-candle-cove-the-scariest-childrens-show-of-all-time/|title=CREEPYPASTA: Revisiting CANDLE COVE — The Scariest Children’s Show of All Time?|last=Burkart|first=Gregory|date=2016-08-25|website=Blumhouse.com|access-date=2016-10-19}} Straub's story quickly became popular, inspiring numerous [[YouTube]] videos, and fan-fictions.{{Cite news|url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/do-you-remember-candle-cove|title=Do You Remember Candle Cove?|last=Grundhauser|first=Eric|date=2016-10-07|work=|newspaper=Atlas Obscura|access-date=2016-10-19|via=}} In 2015 Straub self-published ''Candle Cove'' in a collection of short stories entitled ''Candle Cove and Other Stories''. [[The Verge]] commented that ''Candle Cove'' differed from other creepypastas in that while most creepypasta have an "anonymous folkloric quality", ''Candle Cove'''s originated from a known source and author.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/7/1/8879963/syfy-channel-zero-candle-cove-max-landis|title=SyFy is making a TV series based on one of the internet's best scary stories|last=Robertson|first=Adi|date=2015-07-01|website=The Verge|access-date=2016-08-10}} A television adaptation, ''[[Channel Zero: Candle Cove]]'', premiered on [[Syfy]] on October 11, 2016. ==Synopsis== The story is told via a thread on a forum called the "NetNostalgia Forums", where a group of users discuss an unusual television show, ''Candle Cove''. The show is about a young girl named Janice, who imagines herself to be friends with pirates. The pirate characters are said to be portrayed by puppets. As the users continue to reminisce they begin to recall more disturbing details about the show, such as a character known as the "Skin-Taker", a skeleton pirate who wears clothing made out of children's skin, and an episode that consisted entirely of the puppets flailing and screaming. The story closes with a user stating that they had recently visited their mother, who revealed that during the times the user said they were watching ''Candle Cove'', all the mother saw on the TV was [[Noise (video)|static]]. ==Television adaptation== {{Main article|Channel Zero (TV series)}} In 2015 the [[Syfy|SyFy Channel]] announced their intent to adapt the ''Candle Cove'' story as the first season of a newly announced series, ''Channel Zero''.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/11/channel-zero-syfy-series-greenlight-candle-cove-1201628879/|title=‘Channel Zero’ Anthology Series Gets Greenlight From Syfy For 2-Season Run|website=Deadline.com|last1=Hipes|first1=Patrick|accessdate=28 July 2016}} The season, named after the creepypasta, expands on the story and centers on a child psychologist who has returned home in order to investigate the 1980s disappearances of his brother and other children.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/syfy-prepping-anthology-based-web-806074|title=Syfy Prepping Anthology Based on Web Horror Phenomenon 'Creepypasta'|last=Goldberg|first=Leslie|date=June 30, 2015|website=The Hollywood Reporter|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-10}} ''Channel Zero: Candle Cove'' stars [[Paul Schneider (actor)|Paul Schneider]] and [[Fiona Shaw]], and premiered on October 11, 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/08/03/syfy-incorporated-z-nation-premiere-dates|title=Syfy sets premiere dates for 'Incorporated,' 'Van Helsing,' more|last=Abrams|first=Natalie|date=August 3, 2016|website=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-10}} ==Reception== Will Wiles of ''[[Aeon (digital magazine)|Aeon]]'' wrote that ''Candle Cove'' was "among the best creepypastas out there" and a good example of using the messageboard and forum format as a storytelling tactic.{{Cite web|url=https://aeon.co/essays/creepypasta-is-how-the-internet-learns-our-fears|title=‘Creepypasta’ is how the internet learns our fears|last=Wiles|first=Will|date=|website=Aeon|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-10}}{{Cite web|url=http://io9.gizmodo.com/is-creepypasta-a-form-of-folklore-1495902436|title=Has Creepypasta Reinvented Classic Folklore?|last=Newitz|first=Annalee|date=|website=io9|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-10}} The Verge has written praise for the creepypasta, stating that it was "a perfectly dark spin on our nostalgia for the half-remembered stories of our childhood, that realization that the things we liked as kids were much, much creepier than we thought." ==References== {{reflist}} {{Infobox journal | title = Cliometrica | cover = Cliometrica.jpg | editor = Claude Diebolt | discipline = [[Economics]], [[history]] | abbreviation = Cliometrica | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | country = | frequency = Three times a year | history = 2007 - present | impact = | impact-year = | website = https://www.springer.com/economics/economic+theory/journal/11698 | JSTOR = | OCLC = 128596204 | LCCN = | ISSN = 1863-2505 | eISSN = 1863-2513 }} '''''Cliometrica''''' is an [[academic journal]] about [[economic history]]. It follows the quantitative or formal approaches that have been called [[cliometrics]] or the [[new economic history]], applied to any place and time. These formal approaches apply mathematical economic theory, model building, and statistical estimation.<ref>[https://www.springer.com/economics/economic+theory/journal/11698 Official web site of ''Cliometrica: Journal of Historical Economics and Econometric History'']</ref>
The journal's first issues came out in 2007. It is published by [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]. Since its founding its publication director and managing editor has been Claude Diebolt.<ref>[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11698-015-0136-z ''Cliometrica after 10 years: definition and principles of cliometric research'']</ref>
Articles from the earliest issues can be downloaded through [http://econpapers.repec.org/article/afccliome/ econpapers.repec.org].

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{update|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox political party |name = Congress of the People |logo = Congress of the People logo.svg |colorcode = {{Congress of the People (South African political party)/meta/color}} |leader = |chairperson = Pakes Dikgetsi |president = [[Mosiuoa Lekota]] |secretary_general = Lyndall Shope-Mafole |spokesperson = Denis Bloem |founder = [[Mosiuoa Lekota]], [[Mbhazima Shilowa]] and [[Mluleki George]] |leader1_title = [[Deputy President]] |leader1_name = [[William Mothipa Madisha]] |leader2_title = Deputy Secretary General |leader2_name = Deidre Carter |leader3_title = Treasurer |slogan = Reliable, Accountable, Incorruptible |founded = {{Start date|2008|12|16|df=y}} |dissolved = |split = [[African National Congress]] |headquarters = 34–36 Fricker Road, [[Illovo, Gauteng|Illovo]], [[Gauteng]] |student_wing = COPE Students Movement [COPESM] |youth_wing = COPE Youth Movement [COPEYM] |wing1_title = [[Women's wing]] |wing1 = COPE Women's Movement [COPEWM] |wing2_title = [[Business and Professionals' wing]] |wing2 = COPE Business and Professionals |ideology = [[Social democracy]]
[[Social liberalism]]
[[Progressivism]] |position = [[Centre-left]] |national = [[Collective for Democracy]] |colours = {{color box|#F9C217}} Yellow {{color box|#BE1E2D}} Red |seats1_title = [[National Assembly (South Africa)|National Assembly]] seats |seats1 = {{Composition bar|3|400|hex={{Congress of the People (South African political party)/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[National Council of Provinces|NCOP]] seats |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|90|hex={{Congress of the People (South African political party)/meta/color}}}} |seats3_title = [[Provincial_legislature_(South_Africa)|Provincial Legislatures]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|3|430|hex={{Congress of the People (South African political party)/meta/color}}}} |flag = Congress of the People flag.svg |website = {{URL|www.congressofthepeople.org.za/}} |country = South Africa }} The '''Congress of the People (COPE)''' is a South African political party formed in 2008 by former members of the [[African National Congress]] (ANC).{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7784763.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=New party to challenge ANC rule|date=16 December 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} The party was founded by former ANC members [[Mosiuoa Lekota]], [[Mbhazima Shilowa]] and [[Mluleki George]] to contest the [[South African general election, 2009|2009 general election]]. The party was announced following a national convention held in [[Sandton]] on 1 November 2008, and was founded at a congress held in [[Bloemfontein]] on 16 December 2008. The name echoes the 1955 [[Congress of the People (1955)|Congress of the People]] at which the [[Freedom Charter]] was adopted by the ANC and other parties, a name strongly contested by the ANC in a legal move dismissed by the [[Pretoria]] High Court.{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=904235|title=Cope wins name battle|work=The Times|location=UK|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221011535/http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=904235|archivedate=21 December 2008|df=dmy-all}} In the 2009 general election, the party received 1,311,027 votes and a 7.42% share of the vote. Following the 2009 elections, COPE experienced a leadership dispute between factions supporting Mosiuoa Lekota and others supporting Mbhazima Shilowa,{{cite web|url=http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2011/05/13/infighting-necessary---cope|title='Infighting necessary' - Cope|date=13 May 2011|website=www.sowetanlive.co.za}} that led to a 2013 court battle,{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/shilowa-row-goes-back-to-court-1598059|title=Shilowa row goes back to court|publisher=IOL News|author=Shanti Aboobaker|date=27 October 2013|accessdate=21 November 2018}} and continued into 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2014/01/07/cope-factions-headed-for-court-battle|author=Khulekani Magubane|title=COPE factions headed for court battle|website=www.bdlive.co.za|date=7 January 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114000244/http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2014/01/07/cope-factions-headed-for-court-battle|archivedate=14 January 2014|deadurl=yes|accessdate=7 January 2014}} After the [[South African general election, 2014|2014 election]], COPE was left with only three seats in the National Assembly, down from 30 seats in 2009.{{cite web|title=Only COPE has lost more seats than ANC|publisher=BDlive|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2014/05/09/only-cope-has-lost-more-seats-than-anc|date=9 May 2014|accessdate=11 May 2014|deadurl=yes|archivedate=11 May 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140511030029/http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/politics/2014/05/09/only-cope-has-lost-more-seats-than-anc}} Despite its reduced stature, the party has joined with the much larger [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]] (DA) and several other smaller parties to co-govern [[Nelson Mandela Bay Metropolitan Municipality|Nelson Mandela Bay]], [[City of Johannesburg Metropolitan Municipality|Johannesburg]] and [[City of Tshwane Metropolitan Municipality|Tshwane]] after the 2016 municipal elections. ==History== ===52nd ANC national conference=== {{Main|52nd National Conference of the African National Congress}} The birth of the party can be traced back to the 52nd ANC national conference held at Polokwane in December 2007. The conference resulted in the election of [[Jacob Zuma]] and his supporters, ahead of [[Thabo Mbeki]] and his supporters, to the ANC's governing body, the [[National Executive Committee]]. Zuma was elected ANC president ahead of Mbeki. The conference highlighted the different factions within the ANC and brought to the fore the diametrically opposed philosophies between Mbeki and Zuma. This included differences in both style and economic policy – the former pursued [[neoliberal]] economic policies and was known for an aloof personality and plotting against his political opponents,{{cite news|title=Hundreds burn ANC cards in Paarl|author=Lynnette Johns|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/hundreds-burn-anc-cards-in-paarl-421807|publisher=Independent Online (IOL)|date=26 October 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} while his successor is more left-wing and populist, and has a closer relationship with the [[South African Communist Party]] and [[Congress of South African Trade Unions]].{{cite news|author=Plaut, Martin|accessdate=21 November 2018|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7627882.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Why Mbeki had to go|date=21 September 2008}} The split also revealed underlying ethnic tensions between [[Zulu language|Zulu]] and [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]] speakers, represented by Jacob Zuma and Thabo Mbeki respectively, as they jostled for political predominance.{{cite news|author=Plaut, Martin|accessdate=21 November 2018|title=S Africa's ANC on brink of split|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7695492.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=31 October 2008}} ===Zuma corruption trial and recall of Mbeki=== Jacob Zuma, now elected president of the ANC and ANC candidate for President in the South Africa at the 2009 election, was facing corruption charges in relation to a [[South African Arms Deal|multi-billion rand arms deal]] with French manufacturer [[Thint]]. Zuma had previously been dismissed by Mbeki as South Africa's vice-president at the start of the arms deal trial. In 2008 a landmark ruling by high court judge [[Christopher Robert Nicholson|Chris Nicholson]] found that the re-charging of Zuma by the [[National Prosecuting Authority]] was illegal and was unduly influenced by Mbeki due to political motives. The case against Zuma was thus dismissed. As a consequence of the judge's findings of political interference, the ANC's National Executive Committee requested the recall of Mbeki as the country's president. Mbeki tendered his resignation on 21 September 2008 and the resignation became official on 25 September. Many members of Mbeki's cabinet resigned their posts at the same time in solidarity, including vice-president [[Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka]] and other senior cabinet ministers. The recall of Mbeki brought to the fore simmering tensions within the ANC. On 23 September Mosiuoa Lekota announced that he had served the ANC with "divorce papers" and on 8 October announced that a national convention would be held to discuss the future of South African politics and the possible formation of a new political movement. Lekota's call resounded with many Mbeki supporters who started handing in their resignations to the ANC to join Lekota's movement. Notable resignations include those of former [[Gauteng]] premier [[Mbhazima Shilowa]], former [[Western Cape]] minister of safety and security [[Leonard Ramatlakane]] and [[Mluleki George]]. Across the country many regular ANC members also handed in their resignations in public demonstrations, burning their ANC membership cards. The resignation movement resounded particularly in provinces in which there were already splits in the ANC structure, such as the [[Western Cape]]. ===Convention and formation of new party=== The convention called by Lekota was held in [[Sandton]] on 1 November 2008. Planned for 4,000 delegates over two days, the conference eventually hosted over 5,000, with some people not able to get into the venue, and was shortened to one day to avoid inconvenience to those delegates who had nowhere to stay overnight.{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/shikota-convention-oversubscribed-422704|title='Shikota' convention oversubscribed|publisher=IOL News|date=1 November 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} The conference was attended by major political figures, including delegates from other political parties. The ANC did not send a delegation to the conference. Following the conference Lekota announced that a new party would be formed on 16 December. In Western Cape municipal by-elections on 11 December 2008, COPE won 10 of 27 wards (with its candidates running as independents, as it was not yet registered); the ANC won only three wards, with twelve of its candidates disqualified due to missing the registration deadline. The DA won nine seats.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7777998.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=ANC breakaway scores poll upset|date=11 December 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} The party was formally launched at a three-day conference from 14 to 16 December 2008,{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/16/AR2008121600130.html?wprss=rss_world|title=New Party Formally Launched in South Africa|work=The Washington Post}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} at which Lekota was named president. ===2009 general election=== [[File:South Africa national election 2009 COPE vote by ward.svg|thumb|right|Proportion of votes cast for COPE in the 2009 election, by ward. {{legend|#feedde|0–20%}} {{legend|#fdbe85|20–40%}} {{legend|#fd8d3c|40–60%}} {{legend|#e6550d|60–80%}} {{legend|#a63603|80–100%}}]] {{Main|South African general election, 2009}} The party faced its first general election in 2009. Their election manifesto{{cite web |url=http://www.africafiles.org/article.asp?ID=19962|title=A New Agenda for Change and Hope for All|publisher=Africa Files|accessdate=21 November 2018}} was launched on 24 January 2009 and included calls for electoral reform to have the president, provincial premiers and municipal mayors directly elected.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7849134.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=New SA party promises reforms|date=24 January 2009|accessdate=21 November 2018}} South Africa currently has a pure [[proportional representation]] system with parties submitting lists of candidates in order of preference. The president and provincial premiers and mayors (after municipal elections) are subsequently elected by the members of the relevant assembly. On 20 February 2009, they announced clergyman [[Mvume Dandala]] as their presidential candidate.{{cite news|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2009-02-20-bishop-elbows-aside-lekota-shilowa|title=Bishop elbows aside Lekota, Shilowa|work=[[Mail & Guardian]]|author1=Mandy Rossouw|author2=Mmanaledi Mataboge|date=20 February 2009|accessdate=21 November 2018}} A COPE official was murdered in the Eastern Cape,{{cite news|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/world/world/general/politician-killed-as-south-africans-vote/1495225.aspx|title=Politician killed as South Africans vote|work=Canberra Times|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014090009/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/world/world/general/politician-killed-as-south-africans-vote/1495225.aspx|archivedate=14 October 2009|df=dmy-all}} and COPE supporters, from the Eastern Cape, were driven out of their shacks in Durban.[http://reconciliationbarometer.org/?page_id=2884 Political tolerance on the wane in South Africa], Imraan Buccus, University of KwaZulu-Natal, ''SA Reconciliation Barometer''. Retrieved 21 November 2018. The party achieved the leadership of the opposition in the legislatures of Eastern Cape, Free State, Limpopo and Northern Cape and representation in all nine provinces. ==Election results== ===National elections=== {{election table|editlink=no}} |- !Election !Total votes !Share of vote !Seats !+/– !Government |- ![[South African general election, 2009|2009]] |align=right|1,311,027 |align=right|7.42% |{{Composition bar|30|400|hex={{Congress of the People (South African political party)/meta/color}}}} | – |{{no2|in opposition}} |- ![[South African general election, 2014|2014]] |align=right|123,235 |align=right|0.67% |{{Composition bar|3|400|hex={{Congress of the People (South African political party)/meta/color}}}} |{{decrease}} 27 |{{no2|in opposition}} |} ===Provincial elections=== {{election table|editlink=no}} !rowspan=2|Election !colspan=2|[[Eastern Cape]] !colspan=2|[[Free State (South African province)|Free State]] !colspan=2|[[Gauteng]] !colspan=2|[[KwaZulu-Natal|Kwazulu-Natal]] !colspan=2|[[Limpopo]] !colspan=2|[[Mpumalanga]] !colspan=2|[[North West (South African province)|North-West]] !colspan=2|[[Northern Cape]] !colspan=2|[[Western Cape]] |- !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats !%!!Seats |- ![[South African general election, 2009|2009]] |13.67%||9/63 |11.61%||4/30 |7.78%||6/73 |1.29%||1/80 |7.53%||4/49 |2.91%||1/30 |8.33%||3/33 |16.67%||5/30 |7.74%||3/42 |- ![[South African general election, 2014|2014]] |1.20%||1/63 |1.63%||0/30 |0.49%||0/73 |0.16%||0/80 |0.86%||1/49 |0.32%||0/30 |0.94%||0/33 |3.60%||1/30 |0.59%||0/42 |} ===Municipal elections=== {{election table|editlink=no}} |- !Election !Votes !% |- ![[South African municipal election, 2011|2011]] |570,698 |2.1% |- ![[South African municipal election, 2016|2016]]{{cite web|url=http://www.elections.org.za/content/LGEPublicReports/402/Detailed%20Results/National.pdf|title=Results Summary - All Ballots|publisher=elections.org.za|accessdate=21 November 2018}} |186,185 |0.48% |- |} ==Leadership elected at first National Congress== [[File:Mosiuoa Lekota, 000215-D-9880W-112 detail.jpg|thumb|[[Mosiuoa Lekota]]]] The elected leadership of the party consists of the following:{{cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Lekota-re-elected-Cope-president-20140111|work=news24.com|title=Lekota re-elected Cope president|date=11 January 2014|accessdate=21 November 2018}} *[[Mosiuoa Lekota]] – President *[[William Mothipa Madisha]] – Deputy President *Lyndall Shope-Mafole – Secretary General *Deidre Carter - Deputy Secretary General *Pakes Dikgetsi - National Chairperson *Johnny Huang – Treasurer ==Provincial premiership candidates== COPE's list of provincial premiership candidates was announced in the Sunday Sun newspaper on 2 March 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Cope-releases-list-20090228|title=Cope releases list|date=28 February 2009|website=news24.com|accessdate=21 November 2018}} The list was: *[[Lyndall Shope-Mafole]] – Gauteng (female) *[[Nikiwe Num]] – North West (female) *[[Prudence Madonsela]] – Mpumulanga (female) *[[Wiseman Nkuhlu]] – Eastern Cape *[[Allan Boesak]] – Western Cape *[[Neville Mompati]] – Northern Cape *[[Casca Mokitlane]] – Free State *[[Lucky Sifiso Gabela]] – KwaZulu-Natal The premiership candidate for Limpopo was announced at a later date: *[[Sello Moloto]] – Limpopo{{cite news|url=https://www.sanews.gov.za/south-africa/limpopos-newly-elected-premier-announces-his-exco|title=Limpopo's newly elected premier announces his Exco|author=Nthambeleni Gabara|date=6 May 2009|accessdate=21 November 2018}} ==Reactions== ===Reaction from the ANC and alliance partners=== The ANC leadership reacted by offering a reconciliation meeting between treasurer [[Mathews Phosa]] and Lekota and his former deputy defense minister Mluleki George on 13 October. However, the meeting ended without resolution. On 14 October, Lekota and George were suspended from membership in the ANC by the [[National Executive Committee (African National Congress)|National Executive Committee]], with threats of suspension against any other members who sought to join Lekota and George. Both Zuma and then [[ANC Youth League]] president [[Julius Malema]] ridiculed Lekota for the announcement. ===Support from within the ANC=== On 15 October, former [[Gauteng]] premier [[Mbhazima Shilowa]], who resigned from his position soon after Mbeki and the cabinet resigned, announced that he had resigned his membership from the ANC and thrown his support behind Lekota's convention, which he announced would be held on 2 November.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7671292.stm|title=ANC heavyweight joins rebellion|publisher=BBC News|date=15 October 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} The partnership between Lekota and Shilowa led the press to nickname the proposed new party "Shikota". Former Western Cape community safety minister [[Leonard Ramatlakane]] resigned from the ANC on 22 October to join Lekota's initiative. On 3 November, former Eastern Cape premier [[Nosimo Balindlela]] announced her resignation from the ANC in order to join the proposed new party.{{cite news|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/Balindlela-resigns-from-ANC-20081103|title=Balindlela resigns from ANC|publisher=News24|date=3 November 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} On 13 November 2008, [[Smuts Ngonyama]], the former head of communications for ANC, joined the breakaway movement.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7727278.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=S Africa's ANC loses top official|date=13 November 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} ===Reaction from other parties=== [[Helen Zille]] of the [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]], [[Bantu Holomisa]] of the [[United Democratic Movement]] and [[Mangosuthu Buthelezi]] of the [[Inkatha Freedom Party]] all welcomed the announcement, saying that a new party in opposition to the ANC would diversify the political landscape and pull South Africa from being an effectively [[dominant-party system]]. ==Prominent supporters== COPE has attracted the support of a wide range of well-known South Africans from various sectors, including Sipho Ngwema, former head of communications for the [[Scorpions (South Africa)|Scorpions]] who is now the party's media liaison chief,{{cite news|author=Fiona Forde|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/ex-scorpion-bigwig-joins-cope-info-team-427415|title=Ex-Scorpion bigwig joins COPE info team|publisher=Independent Online|date=1 December 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} and cleric [[Allan Boesak]]{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/boesak-joins-cope-429091|title=Boesak joins COPE|publisher=Independent Online|date=16 December 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} who ran in the 2009 election as COPE's Western Cape premier candidate.{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/boesak-for-western-cape-premier-429173|author=Gaye Davis|author2=Andisiwe Makinana|title=Boesak for Western Cape premier?|publisher=Independent Online|date=17 December 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} Other prominent supporters include the wife of [[Vusi Pikoli]], the former head of the National Prosecuting Authority, and [[Simon Grindrod]], former deputy president of the [[Independent Democrats]]. [[Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka]], former deputy president under [[Thabo Mbeki]], and [[Saki Macozoma]], a prominent South African billionnaire and close ally of Mbeki, joined COPE in late February 2009.{{cite news|url=https://www.mg.co.za/article/2009-03-01-phumzile-macozoma-throw-lot-in-with-cope|title=Phumzile, Macozoma defect to Cope|work=Mail & Guardian|date=1 March 2009|accessdate=21 November 2018}} Macozoma's affiliation to the party was accidentally leaked by Mbhazima Shilowa himself in London, United Kingdom, in the third week of January 2009[http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2009/01/22/SK/13/vryburger22jan.html Onkundige kundiges en kansvatters – Media24 Archive] (in Afrikaans) ''Die Burger''. 22 January 2009. Mlambo-Ngcuka who is best known for her statement that South Africa could learn from Zimbabwe with regard to land reform.{{cite web|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2005-08-10-land-reform-sa-should-learn-from-zimbabwe|title=Land reform: SA should 'learn from Zimbabwe'|work=Mail & Guardian|date=10 August 2005|accessdate=21 November 2018}} ==Policy== In an interview with ''The Sunday Times'',{{cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/mosiuoa-terror-lekota-threatens-to-topple-the-anc-wmt7ttt3fgz|title=Mosiuoa 'Terror' Lekota threatens to topple the ANC|author=RW Johnson|work=The Sunday Times|location=London|date=19 October 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} Lekota stated that the ideology of the party will be one that embraces multiracial and multicultural participation in governance, promoting of the free market and disavowed themselves from any connection to [[Marxism]]. He has also indicated that the party would be willing to ally itself with the Democratic Alliance, a historically liberal party, in the case that the DA ever enters government. According to the party's manifesto flyer,http://www.copewebsite.co.za/documents/cope_manifesto.pdf {{Dead link|date=July 2010}} COPE's campaign topics for the 2009 elections are maintaining the constitutional status quo, unemployment, job satisfaction, poverty, the environment, secondary and tertiary education, health care in general, crime, women empowerment, youth development, family values, and future [[non-racialism]]. A main distinction between COPE and the ruling ANC party is that COPE favours a system in which top-level government officials are elected directly, by public election, and officials can be removed only by courts of justice, whereas the current situation in South Africa is that top-level government officials are appointed and can be removed from office by the political parties themselves. ==Controversies== ===Party name=== Before settling on the name ''Congress of the People'' and the abbreviation ''COPE'', several possible names were used or suggested by the party founders themselves and through speculation in the media. During a public meeting on 12 October 2008 in Langa, where Lekota was the speaker, membership forms for a possible new party, bearing the name ''African National Congress of South Africa (ANCSA)'', were distributed.[http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2008/10/13/KS/5/sslekota.html ANC-afstigters maak stem dik, kry naam, organiseer – Media24 Archive] (in Afrikaans) ''Die Burger'' {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529061959/http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2008/10/13/KS/5/sslekota.html |date=29 May 2011}} On 31 October 2008, one day prior to the new party's convention in Sandton, the ANC made an urgent application to the high court to prevent the new party from using names such as ''South Africa National Convention'', ''South Africa National Congress'', ''SANC'' or any other name or trademark that is similar to its own.{{cite news|url=http://stage.dieburger.com/Stories/News/18.0.1035528913.aspx|title=Nasionale konvensie vandag: Dis ANC teen (S)ANC|work=Die Burger|author=Verslagspan Pretoria|language=Afrikaans|date=31 October 2008}} The judge ruled that the convention may go ahead, but did make a ruling on the names issue until 6 November.{{cite web|url=http://jv.dieburger.com//Stories/Opinion/18.0.1077588798.aspx|title=As partye naam wil maak|work=Die Burger|author=Carien du Plessis|language=Afrikaans|date=14 November 2008}} At the new party's Sandton convention, the name ''South African Democratic Congress (SADC)'' was also proposed,[http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2008/11/04/KS/6/SSshikota.html Party soek nog naam – Media24 Archive] ''Die Burger'' (in Afrikaans){{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529062006/http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2008/11/04/KS/6/SSshikota.html|date=29 May 2011}} but it was later discovered by them that this was already being used by [[South African Democratic Congress|another party]] that was due to contest the 2009 election.{{cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/name-problems-for-shikota-422832|title=Name problems for Shikota|publisher=Independent Online|date=3 November 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} By 15 November, the name ''Congress of the People'' was chosen, and its official abbreviation was chosen to be ''COPE'', not ''COP''.{{cite news|url=http://jv.dieburger.com//Stories/News/18.0.1067100773.aspx|title=Nuwe party kan nog struikel op pad na registrasie|author=Pieter du Toit|work=Die Burger|language=Afrikaans|date=12 November 2011}} When the name settled on was the ''Congress of the People'', the ANC announced they would challenge this name as well.{{cite news|title=ANC takes issue with COP over name|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2008-11-11-anc-takes-issue-with-cop-over-name|work=Mail & Guardian|date=11 November 2008|accessdate=21 November 2018}} The ANC's application to the Pretoria Provincial Division of the High Court for an interdict to prevent COPE from using the name Congress of the People, cited that the ANC itself was affiliated to the [[Congress of the People (1955)|1955 Congress of the People]], held in [[Kliptown]]. On 12 December 2008, the court ruled that COPE would not be barred from using its present name. ===Allan Boesak=== The elevation of Boesak to the COPE leadership, given his record as a convicted malefactor, drew considerable censure from press and public alike. It was intimated that the party's self-projection as a morally pure alternative had been sullied. On 5 February 2009, on his [[Facebook]] page, Lekota urged supporters:
We should also not be distracted now by who serves in the interim leadership, because ultimately the people's voice will be heard. They will vote for their leaders, and everyone else will apply for a job and be interviewed to obtain any position. So, you see, I am not bothered by who joins COPE, or if the individual has a criminal record, or not. Is it not so, that if a gangster goes to church, he expects to dance to [[gospel music]], not [[kwaito]]? He's fully aware of what music determines the song and dance in church. No-one is forced to join COPE – people join voluntarily, fully aware of what the organisation stands for. So, why worry about who joins? Let them; they'll dance to our music!Lekota, Mosiuoa. "[http://www.facebook.com/topic.php?uid=39661395138&topic=6331&ref=mf What does COPE need to do, to win the coming elections?]", [[Facebook]]. 5 February 2009.

{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}} '''Daniel Angelocrator''' (1569 – 1635), real surname Engelhardt, was a German [[Reformed]] [[minister (Christianity)|minister]].
==Life== He was born on 19 October 1569 in [[Korbach]]. He studied theology at the [[University of Marburg]] and [[University of Franeker]] from 1588 to 1589. Angelocrater then took a job accompanying two young aristocrats to the Universities of Marburg and [[Helmstedt]]. In 1594 he clashed with his father over his Calvinism, moved to [[Geneva]] and stayed with a former pupil.
Angelocrater then was employed in the High School of [[Stade]]. From 1597 to 1606 he was a prominent minister in [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Kassel|Hesse-Kassel]], in various cities. [[Maurice, Landgrave of Hesse-Kassel]] in 1607 made him Archdeacon of Marburg, and 1614 the Superintendent. He was one of the delegates to the [[Synod of Dort]] in 1618.
In the [[Thirty Years' War]] the neighbouring [[Lutheran]] state of [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Darmstadt|Hesse-Darmstadt]] was opposed to Hesse-Kassel, and in 1624 Angelocrator had to leave to escape its troops. As minister of [[Gudensberg]], and supervising [[Obervorschütz]], he then lost everything in 1626 to the pillaging Imperial troops of [[Johann Tserclaes, Count of Tilly]]. He was appointed to the [[Consistory (Protestantism)|consistory]] at [[Kassel]], and then went in 1627 to [[Köthen]], where he died on 30 July 1635.
[[File:Angelocrator map.jpg|thumb|right|World map by Daniel Angelocrator from his book ''Novum Orbis Terrarum Schema, in Plano sic Descriptum'', using a projection of his own invention.]]
==Works== He is known, as well as a minister, as a [[chronologist]] for his ''Chronologia Autoptica'' (1601),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfb-frueheneuzeit.uni-muenchen.de/projekte/zusatz/HistorischeTabellenwerke/Engelhardt.html |title=Historische Tabellenwerke - Engelhardt |website=Sfb-frueheneuzeit.uni-muenchen.de |date=2005-04-25 |accessdate=2016-02-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185333/http://www.sfb-frueheneuzeit.uni-muenchen.de/projekte/zusatz/HistorischeTabellenwerke/Engelhardt.html |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> which placed reliance on the works of the forger [[Annius of Viterbo]],<ref>[[:fr:s:Page:Michaud - Biographie universelle ancienne et moderne - 1843 - Tome 1.djvu/710]]</ref> and cartographer for a map in his ''Doctrina de ponderibus, monetis, et mensuris''.

{{unreferenced|date=May 2016}} [[Image:Defence Wikipedia.jpg|thumb|300px|right|deFENCE project. Click to enlarge]] ''''deFENCE'''' is an [[interactive]] [[conceptual art]] project for freedom of cohabitation, designed in such a way as to include each beholder personally. In tradition of [[Marcel Duchamp]], the ''two main roles'' of this exhibit are the work itself, and the person watching it. Only here, the subjective role of the beholder is not the only one. They are personally drawn into the exhibit, by way of a [[mirror]].
The work represents a house, with its door wide open, inviting and welcoming every visitor. Except, a certain visitor is watching this house over a barbed wire fence. On the other hand, this visitor is being watched from the window of the house. The author's intention was to combine these two persons into one, so that people who had never had the chance to be on the other side of the barbed wire, can benefit in two ways: Firstly, they can see how it is to be looking over a barbed wire into a house inviting you, which you cannot reach. And secondly, they can see themselves passively looking from the house at the person outside the fence, doing nothing to remove this segregation. The concept of this project is to bring to the attention of people living in the 'free' world that many of the boundaries that segregate others in a 'non free' world, are created by themselves. Or, at least, they do nothing to remove these boundaries.
The wish of the author is to help remove all boundaries that separate people and worlds. ''Note:'' 'deFENCE' project was created by Gregor Marković from [[Serbia]], in January 2006. It has been selected to take part at the International Design Biennial in St. Etienne, in 2006. [[Category:Conceptual art]] [[Category:Serbian art]] {{art-stub}}

{{About|the narrative device|other uses of "epilogue" and "epilog"|Epilogue (disambiguation)}} An '''epilogue''' or '''epilog''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ἐπίλογος ''epílogos'', "conclusion" from ἐπί ''epi'', "in addition" and λόγος ''logos'', "word") is a piece of writing at the end of a work of literature, usually used to bring closure to the work.<ref name="EpiDevice">{{cite web | url=http://literarydevices.net/epilogue/ | title=Literary Devices: Definition and Examples of Literary Terms: Epilogue|date=2014| publisher=Literary Devices | work=Literary Devices Website | accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> It is presented from the perspective of within the story. When the author steps in and speaks indirectly to the reader, that is more properly considered an [[afterword]]. The opposite is a [[prologue]]—a piece of writing at the ''beginning'' of a work of literature or drama, usually used to open the story and capture interest.<ref name="ProDevice">{{cite web | url=http://literarydevices.net/epilogue/ | title=Literary Devices: Definition and Examples of Literary Terms: Prologue|date=2014| publisher=Literary Devices | work=Literary Devices Website | accessdate=19 July 2014}}</ref> Some genres, for example [[television programs]]<nowiki/> and [[video games]], call the epilog an "outro" patterned on the use of "intro" for "introduction".
==In literature== [[Image:Grandville, Autre Monde, Epilog.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Illustration from ''Un Autre Monde'' epilogue, by [[Jean Ignace Isidore Gérard Grandville|Grandville]].]]
An epilogue is the final [[chapter (books)|chapter]] at the end of a [[narrative|story]] that often serves to reveal the fates of the [[Character (arts)|character]]s. Some epilogues may feature [[Scene (drama)|scenes]] only tangentially related to the subject of the story. They can be used to hint at a sequel or wrap up all the loose ends. They can occur at a significant period of time after the main [[plot (narrative)|plot]] has ended. In some cases, the epilogue is used to allow the main character a chance to "speak freely".
An epilogue can continue in the same narrative style and perspective as the preceding story, although the form of an epilogue can occasionally be drastically different from the overall story. It can also be used as a [[sequel]].
==In film== In [[film]]s, the final scenes may feature a montage of images or clips with a short explanation of what happens to the characters. A few examples of such films are ''[[9 to 5 (film)|9 to 5]]'', ''[[American Graffiti]]'', ''[[National Lampoon's Animal House]]'', ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2]]'', ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'', ''[[Remember the Titans]]'', and ''[[Changeling (film)|Changeling]]''.
There are many films which do not only include a few glimpses of the character's future, but also are based on an epilogue. Most epilogues in films are shown in a dramatic fashion, usually in silence, to commemorate an important happening, for example, the fate of a character in the film.
The epilogue of ''[[La La Land (film)|La La Land]]'' shows a happy ending, an alternative to the actual ending.
In many [[documentaries]] and [[biopics]], the epilogue is text-based, explaining what happened to the subjects after the events covered in the film.
==In video gaming== In [[Video game|video gaming]], epilogues can occur at the end of the story, usually after the [[Credit (creative arts)|credits]] have rolled. An epilogue in a game functions similarly to an epilogue in [[film]] and [[literature]], providing closure to the end of a story.
However, the way in which an epilogue is interacted with in a video game can then determine how a story ends, in works of fiction that contain [[Types of fiction with multiple endings#Video games|multiple endings]]. For example, there are four possible endings to ''[[Spec Ops: The Line]]'', and three of the endings are chosen by what the player does in the epilogue.
In games that feature the [[Permadeath|permanent death]] of [[Player character|playable characters]], an epilogue can chronicle what has happened to the various characters that have survived the events of the game, depicting how their situation has changed after the story has come to a conclusion. For example, the 2015 video game ''[[Until Dawn]]'' features those who survived recounting their experiences to the Police after being rescued. This system can also be expanded on. In most games of the ''[[Fire Emblem]]'' series, relationships can be built between characters, allowing for unique outcomes to happen for characters depending on the actions of the player throughout the campaign.
A [[visual novel]] can also feature a type of epilogue, which will wrap up all of the scenarios encountered by a player, most often after the game has been fully completed by reaching all of the multiple endings; as is the case with ''[[Tsukihime]]'', featuring an epilogue that expands on the endings of all completable routes, as well as providing context for the rest of the game by explaining events in the prologue.
==In television== For many years ''[[The Epilogue]]'', a reflective 5-minute [[sermonette]], was the last programme of the day broadcast on a Sunday evening by [[BBC]] radio and later television. The format was picked up by the independent broadcaster [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] in 1956 and was adopted across its various franchises until 1988.

{{Infobox journal | title = Existenz | cover = | editor = [[Helmut Wautischer]] | discipline = [[Philosophy]] | abbreviation =Existenz | publisher = Open Source | country = United States | frequency = Biannual | history = 2006–present | openaccess = yes | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.existenz.us | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = http://www.existenz.us/pastissues.html | link2-name = Tables of content, 2006-present | JSTOR = | OCLC = 69669109 | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = | eISSN = 1932-1066 }} '''''Existenz''''' is an on-line biannual [[academic journal]] covering research in [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[politics]], and [[the arts]]. Established in 2006 by its founding editors [[Alan M. Olson]] and [[Helmut Wautischer]] and is sponsored by the [[Karl Jaspers Society of North America]]. Its title, ''Existenz'', derives from an essential feature of the philosophy of [[Karl Jaspers]], namely, the notion of ''[[Dasein#Karl Jaspers' Dasein and Existenz|mögliche Existenz]]'' or "possible self-being" for which Jaspers became famous as one of the world's leading [[Existentialism|existentialist philosophers]] in the 20th century.
The journal serves as a publication outlet for Jaspers scholarship, cooperates with various international Jaspers societies, including those in the United States, Japan, Poland, Germany, Austria, Italy, and Croatia, and also considers direct submissions of articles for online publication. ''Existenz'' is indexed by [[Philosopher's Information Center|The Philosopher's Index]] and included in the [[EBSCO Information Services|EBSCO]] database.

[[Image:CrystalPalaceStation.jpg|thumb|right|Use of float glass at [[Crystal Palace railway station]], [[London]]]] '''Float glass''' is a sheet of [[glass]] made by floating molten glass on a bed of molten metal, typically [[tin]], although [[lead]] and various low [[melting point]] alloys were used in the past. This method gives the sheet uniform thickness and very flat surfaces.<ref>{{cite web|title=Step-by-step Manufacturing of Float Glass|url=http://www.pilkington.com/pilkington-information/about+pilkington/education/float+process/step+by+step.htm|publisher=Pilkington|accessdate=18 July 2017}}</ref>
Modern [[window]]s are made from float glass. Most float glass is [[soda-lime glass]], but relatively minor quantities of specialty [[borosilicate]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.schott.com/hometech/english/products/borofloat/index.html|title=Borosilikatglas BOROFLOAT® {{!}} SCHOTT AG|website=www.schott.com|language=en|access-date=2017-07-18}}</ref> and [[flat panel display]] glass are also produced using the float glass process.<ref>Not all flat panel display glass is produced by the float glass process. The company [[Corning Incorporated|Corning]] is using the [[Overflow downdraw method|overflow downdraw technique]], while [[Schott Glass|Schott]] uses the float glass technique (see [http://www.schott.com/fpd/english/lcd_glass/index.html Schott website]).</ref> The float glass process is also known as the '''Pilkington process''', named after the British glass manufacturer [[Pilkington]], which pioneered the technique (invented by Sir [[Alastair Pilkington]]) in the 1950s at their production site in [[St Helens, Merseyside]].
== History == [[File:windowfloatnofloat.jpg|thumb|right|Old [[window]] containing a single sheet of float glass in the upper left section, [[Jena]], [[Germany]]. The remaining sections are possibly not float glass as indicated by the distorted reflections of a tree.]] Until the 16th century, window glass or [[flat glass]] was generally cut from large discs (or rondels) of [[crown glass (window)|crown glass]]. Larger sheets of glass were made by [[glassblowing|blowing]] large [[Cylinder blown sheet|cylinders]] which were cut open and flattened, then cut into panes. Most window glass in the early 19th century was made using the [[cylinder method]]. The 'cylinders' were {{convert|6|to|8|ft|cm}} long and {{convert|10|to|14|in|cm}} in diameter, limiting the width that panes of glass could be cut, and resulting in windows divided by transoms into rectangular panels.
The first advances in automating glass manufacturing were patented in 1848 by [[Henry Bessemer]], an [[England|English]] [[engineer]].<ref>Bessemer, Henry ; British patent no. 12,101 (issued: Sept. 22, 1848).</ref> His system produced a continuous ribbon of flat glass by forming the ribbon between rollers. This was an expensive process, as the surfaces of the glass needed polishing. If the glass could be set on a perfectly smooth, flat body, like the surface of an open pan of calm liquid, this would reduce costs considerably. Attempts were made to form flat glass on a bath of molten tin—one of the few liquids denser than glass that would be calm at the high temperatures needed to make glass—most notably in the US. Several patents were granted,<ref>See: * William E. Heal, [http://pdfpiw.uspto.gov/.piw?Docid=00710357&homeurl=http%3A%2F%2Fpatft.uspto.gov%2Fnetacgi%2Fnph-Parser%3FSect2%3DPTO1%2526Sect2%3DHITOFF%2526p%3D1%2526u%3D%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html%2526r%3D1%2526f%3DG%2526l%3D50%2526d%3DPALL%2526S1%3D0710357.PN.%2526OS%3DPN%2F710357%2526RS%3DPN%2F710357&PageNum=&Rtype=&SectionNum=&idkey=NONE&Input=View+first+page "Manufacture of window and plate glass,"] U.S. patent no. 710,357 (filed: January 25, 1902; issued: September 30, 1902). * Halbert K. Hitchcock, [http://pdfpiw.uspto.gov/.piw?Docid=00789911&homeurl=http%3A%2F%2Fpatft.uspto.gov%2Fnetacgi%2Fnph-Parser%3FSect2%3DPTO1%2526Sect2%3DHITOFF%2526p%3D1%2526u%3D%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html%2526r%3D1%2526f%3DG%2526l%3D50%2526d%3DPALL%2526S1%3D0789911.PN.%2526OS%3DPN%2F789911%2526RS%3DPN%2F789911&PageNum=&Rtype=&SectionNum=&idkey=NONE&Input=View+first+page "Apparatus for manufacturing glass sheets or plates,"] U.S. patent no. 789,911 (filed: July 30, 1902; issued: May 16, 1905).</ref> but this process was unworkable at the time.
Before the development of float glass, larger sheets of plate glass were made by casting a large puddle of glass on an [[iron]] surface, and then polishing both sides, a costly process. From the early 1920s, a continuous ribbon of plate glass was passed through a lengthy series of inline grinders and polishers, reducing glass losses and cost.
Glass of lower quality, drawn glass, was made by drawing upwards from a pool of molten glass a thin sheet, held at the edges by rollers. As it cooled the rising sheet stiffened and could then be cut. The two surfaces were of lower quality i.e. not as smooth or uniform as those of float glass. This process continued in use for many years after the development of float glass.
Between 1953 and 1957, Sir [[Alastair Pilkington]] and Kenneth Bickerstaff of the UK's Pilkington Brothers developed the first successful commercial application for forming a continuous ribbon of glass using a molten [[tin]] bath on which the molten glass flows unhindered under the influence of gravity.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1098/rspa.1969.0212 | title = Review Lecture. The Float Glass Process | first = L. A. B. | last = Pilkington | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences | volume = 314 | issue = 1516 | pages = 1–25 | jstor = 2416528 | year = 1969 | publisher = The Royal Society}}</ref> The success of this process lay in the careful balance of the volume of glass fed onto the bath, where it was flattened by its own weight.<ref name=floatpatent>[http://www.google.com/patents?id=Po1sAAAAEBAJ&dq=2911759 US patent 2911759 – Manufacture of flat glass]</ref> Full scale profitable sales of float glass were first achieved in 1960.
In 1964, CH3 Tank, the first purpose-built float line in the world, was built after the conversion of CH4 Tank. CH1 Tank closed down in 1977 as CH2 Float Line started up. The Pilkington's production line at Cowley Hill, St Helens, the birthplace of float glass, is no longer in operation as of 2014 although Pilkington continue to operate other float glass facilities within the town.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Pilkington boss on Cowley Hill : 'Float glass production losing tens of millions' |url=http://www.sthelensstar.co.uk/news/10794410.Pilks_boss___Float_glass_production_losing_tens_of_millions_/?ref=rl |newspaper=St Helens Star |location=St Helens |date=7 November 2013 |access-date=8 September 2016 }}</ref>
==Manufacture== [[File:Floatglasanlage.jpg|thumb|Float glas line]] Float glass uses common glass-making [[Glass#Glass ingredients|raw materials]], typically consisting of [[sand]], soda ash ([[sodium carbonate]]), [[dolomite]], [[limestone]], and salt cake ([[sodium sulfate]]) etc. Other materials may be used as colourants, [[refining (glass)|refining]] agents or to adjust the physical and chemical properties of the glass. The raw materials are mixed in a [[glass batch|batch]] process, then fed together with suitable [[cullet]] (waste glass), in a controlled ratio, into a furnace where it is heated to approximately 1500 °C. Common flat glass furnaces are 9 m wide, 45 m long, and contain more than 1200 tons of glass. Once molten, the temperature of the glass is stabilised to approximately 1200 °C to ensure a homogeneous [[specific gravity]].
The molten glass is fed into a "tin bath", a bath of molten [[tin]] (about 3–4 m wide, 50 m long, 6 cm deep), from a delivery canal and is poured into the tin bath by a ceramic lip known as the spout lip.<ref name=ullmann>B. H. W. S. de Jong, "Glass"; in ''Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry''; 5th edition, vol. A12, VCH Publishers, Weinheim, Germany, 1989, {{ISBN|3-527-20112-2}}, pp. 365–432.</ref> The amount of glass allowed to pour onto the molten tin is controlled by a gate called a ''tweel''.
Tin is suitable for the float glass process because it has a high specific gravity, is cohesive, and is [[immiscible]] with molten glass. Tin, however, [[Redox|oxidises]] in a natural atmosphere to form [[tin dioxide]] (SnO<sub>2</sub>). Known in the production process as dross, the tin dioxide adheres to the glass. To prevent oxidation, the tin bath is provided with a [[positive pressure]] protective atmosphere of [[nitrogen]] and [[hydrogen]].
The glass flows onto the tin surface forming a floating ribbon with perfectly smooth surfaces on both sides and of even thickness. As the glass flows along the tin bath, the temperature is gradually reduced from 1100 °C until at approximately 600 °C the sheet can be lifted from the tin onto rollers. The glass ribbon is pulled off the bath by rollers at a controlled speed. Variation in the flow speed and roller speed enables glass sheets of varying thickness to be formed. Top rollers positioned above the molten tin may be used to control both the thickness and the width of the glass ribbon.
Once off the bath, the glass sheet passes through a [[lehr (glassmaking)|lehr kiln]] for approximately 100 m, where it is cooled gradually so that it [[Annealing (glass)|anneals]] without strain and does not crack from the temperature change. On exiting the "cold end" of the kiln, the glass is cut by machines.
==Uses== [[File:Green color of float glass.jpg|thumb|A float glass light fitting. Ordinary float glass is green in thicker sheets due to [[Fe2+]] impurities.]] Today, float glass is the most widely used form of glass in consumer products. Due to both its high quality with no additional polishing required and its structural flexibility during production, it can easily be shaped and bent into a variety of forms while in a heated, syrupy state. This makes it ideal for a variety of applications such as
* Automobile glass (e.g. windshields, windows, mirrors) * Mirrors * Furniture (e.g. in tables and shelves) * Insulated glass * Windows and doors
Most forms of specialized glass such as [[toughened glass]], [[frosted glass]], laminated safety glass and soundproof glass consist of standard float glass that has been further processed.
==Market== As of 2009, the world float glass market, not including China and Russia, is dominated by the four companies: [[Asahi Glass]], [[Nippon Sheet Glass|NSG]]/[[Pilkington]], [[Saint-Gobain]], and [[Guardian Industries]]. Other companies include Sise Cam AS, [[PPG Industries|PPG]], Central Glass, Hankuk (HanGlas), Zeledyne, and Cardinal Glass Industries.<ref>[http://www.constructiondigital.com/Flat-glass-market-be-39-million-tons-2010_811 "Flat glass market to be 39 million tons by 2010"]</ref>

'''François Marie Savina''' (20 March 1876 – 23 July 1941<ref name=Michaudp209>Michaud, Jean. ''Historical Dictionary of the Peoples of the Southeast Asian Massif'' (Historical Dictionaries of Peoples and Cultures). [[Scarecrow Press]], April 19, 2006. {{ISBN|0810865033}}, 9780810865037. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=JG619Tq4ElkC&pg=PA209 209].</ref>) was a Frenchman who worked as a Catholic priest and as an anthropologist.<ref name=DiaCha1>Cha, Dia (Learning through folklore series). ''Teaching with Folk Stories of the Hmong: An Activity Book''. Libraries Unlimited, 2000. {{ISBN|1563086689}}, 9781563086687. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=qzjm2V_cx3cC&pg=PA1 1].</ref> For an approximately forty-year period he worked in the [[Upper-Tonkin Vicariate]], [[Hainan]], and [[Laos]].<ref name=Michaudp209/> He studied the [[Hmong people]] of northern Vietnam and Laos as he was asked to spread Christianity to them.<ref name=DiaCha1/> Nicholas Tapp, author of ''The Impossibility of Self: An Essay on the Hmong Diaspora'', described Savina as "One of our earliest informants who is at all frank about the nature of his day-today encounters with the Hmong".<ref name=Tappp67>Tapp, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ib1G-iVWi3AC&pg=PA67 67].</ref> Charles Keith, author of ''Catholic Vietnam: A Church from Empire to Nation'', wrote that Savina was "[t]he most notable" missionary ethnographer of Southeast Asia of his era.<ref name=KeithCharlesp123>Keith, Charles. ''Catholic Vietnam: A Church from Empire to Nation'' (Volume 5 of From Indochina to Vietnam: Revolution and War in a Global Perspective Series). [[University of California Press]], 2012. {{ISBN|0520272471}}, 9780520272477. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=q_3qNhitS_0C&pg=PA123 123].</ref>
Tapp wrote that "Savina spoke Hmong but we do not know how much".<ref name=Tappp68>Tapp, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ib1G-iVWi3AC&pg=PA68 68].</ref> Savina also had studied Chinese. Robert Entenmann, author of "The Myth of [[Sonom]], the Hmong King," wrote that Savina "was unfamiliar with Chinese history and the subtleties of Chinese vocabulary".<ref name=Entenmannp6>Entenmann, Robert ([[St. Olaf College]]). "[http://hmongstudies.org/EntenmannHSJ6.pdf The Myth of Sonom, the Hmong King]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6QyjDhsaM Archive]). ''[[Hmong Studies Journal]]'', Volume 6, 2005. Retrieved on July 11, 2014. p. 6.</ref>
==History== He was born in [[Brittany]], [[France]]. In 1901 he arrived in [[Tonkin]] after having joined the [[Société des Missions-Etrangères de Paris]] (MEP).<ref name=Michaudp209/> He was 25 years old at the time.<ref name=Culasp114>Culas, Christian. ''Le messianisme hmong aux 19e et 20e siècles. La dynamique religieuse comme instrument politique'' (Chemins de l'ethnologie, ISSN 1257-9947). [[Les Editions de la MSH]] ([[:fr:Fondation Maison des sciences de l'homme|FR]]), 2005. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ny-H_JjlLFEC&pg=PA114 114]. {{ISBN|2735116670}}, 9782735116676.</ref>
Initially Savina worked with Hmong in [[Lào Cai]], [[Vietnam]].<ref name=Culasp114/> From 1906 to 1925 Savina worked with the [[Hmong people]] in [[Yunnan]], China,<ref name=Tappp67/><ref name=Culasp114/> and also with Hmong in northern [[French Indochina]].<ref name=Tappp67/> From 1918 to 1921 Savina had an official assignment in Laos. Beginning in 1925 he worked as an ethnographic field research representative of the [[École française d'Extrême-Orient]] (EFEO). During that assignment he was based in Hainan and made frequent trips to [[Hong Kong]] where he interacted with a printing house of the MEP. This assignment ended in 1928.<ref name=Michaudp209/>
He resumed his missionary activities in 1939 and moved to [[Ha Giang]] in Upper Tonkin. He was hospitalized in [[Hanoi]] after he came down with [[pneumonia]] in March 1941. At age 65 he died on July 23 of that year.<ref name=Michaudp209/>
==Publications== Savina collected his own data to build eight dictionaries of languages of Southeast Asia, including those in highland and lowland areas. The dictionaries and four [[lexicons]] he wrote combined have a total of over 5,000 pages; these were published from 1911 to 1939.<ref name=Michaudp209/> Savina also wrote histories and ethnographic texts.<ref name=KeithCharlesp123/> Many of his works are about the Hmong people.<ref name=Tappp67/> Savina's publications discuss the [[Ao language|Ao]], [[Be language|Be]], Chinese, [[Day language|Day]], [[Hiai language|Hiai]], [[Hokkien|Hoklo]], [[Miao language|Miao]], [[Nung language (Tai)|Nung]], [[Tay language|Tay]], and Vietnamese languages.<ref name=Michaudp209/> His works appeared in academic journals of the era.<ref name=KeithCharlesp123/>
Savina wrote ''[[Histoire des Miao]]'', published in 1924, and ''Monographie de [[Hainan]]'' ("Monograph of Hainan Island"), published in 1929. Of Savina's writings, ''Histoire des Miao'' is the most well-known and the most often cited.<ref name=Michaudp209/> He wrote a 1920 confidential report titled "Rapport politique sur la révolte des Méos au Tonkin et au Laos."<ref name=Culasp114/>
==References== * Tapp, Nicholas. ''The Impossibility of Self: An Essay on the Hmong Diaspora'' (Volume 6 of Comparative anthropological studies in society, cosmology and politics). [[LIT Verlag Münster]], 2010. {{ISBN|3643102585}}, 9783643102584.

Hammel (2009) "George William Skinner, a biographical memoir." National Academy of Sciences. [http://books.nap.edu/html/biomems/gskinner.pdf]{{cite journal|last1=Verdery|first1=Katherine|last2=Smith|first2=Carol A.|title=George William Skinner (1925-2008)|journal=American Anthropologist|date=September 2009|volume=111|issue=3|pages=398–401|doi=10.1111/j.1548-1433.2009.01148_1.x|ref=harv}}{{cite journal |last= Yu |first=Shuenn-Der Yu |date=2010 |title=In Memory of G. William Skinner: His Contributions to Anthropology |journal=Taiwan Journal of Anthropology |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=3–14 |url=http://www.ioe.sinica.edu.tw/WebTools/FilesDownload.ashx?Siteid=530367210274542025&Menuid=530402741106444121&TB=PeriodicalsContent&CN=PCID&fd=Periodicals_PDF&CNV=PDF&Pname=f96be09a-4717.pdf&MSID=2}} Skinner was a proponent of the spatial approach to Chinese history, as explained in his Presidential Address to the [[Association for Asian Studies]] in 1984.{{cite journal|last1=Skinner|first1=G. William |title=Presidential Address: The Structure of Chinese History |journal=The Journal of Asian Studies |date=February 1985 |volume=44 |issue=2 |pages=271 |doi=10.2307/2055923}} He often referred to his approach as "regional analysis," and taught the use of maps as a key class of data in [[ethnography]]. ==Early life== Skinner was born on February 14, 1925, in [[Oakland, California]]. His father, [[John James Skinner]] was a pharmacologist and his mother, [[Eunice Engle Skinner]], taught music and became the director of music education for the Berkeley school system. Skinner spent two years at [[Deep Springs College]], a small college founded to educate small cohorts of young men into the life of the mind in a self-sufficient, disciplined manner. After Deep Springs, he joined the Navy [[V-12 Navy College Training Program|V-12 Program]] in 1943, then attended the U.S. [[Navy Oriental Language School]] for 18 months at the [[University of Colorado, Boulder]], where he studied Chinese. In 1946, Skinner headed for [[Cornell University]] to complete his B.A. degree. He graduated in the following year with his B.A. (with distinction) in [[Far Eastern Studies]], and remained there for his Ph.D. in anthropology (1954) under the supervision of [[Lauriston Sharp]]. ==Academic career== Skinner’s first job was as instructor in sociology at Cornell in 1949. Late in that year he flew to [[Chengdu]], in China's Sichuan province, to conduct doctoral dissertation research on the structure of markets in the Chengdu Plain. Skinner's research was cut short by the arrival of the [[People's Liberation Army]], which confiscated his notes, but the experience became the basis of his later work on spatial modelling. Skinner proceeded to Bangkok, Thailand, where he researched a substitute doctoral topic, the social structure of the Chinese community in Thailand. This research was published in his first two books, ''Chinese Society in Thailand'' (1957) and ''Leadership and Power in the Chinese Community of Thailand'' (1958) {{sfnp|Harrell|2009|p=454}} Between 1951 and 1955, he was field director of the [[Cornell Southeast Asia Program]], then a research associate at Cornell. He became assistant professor of anthropology at [[Columbia University]] in 1958. Two years later, Skinner was hired back at Cornell as associate professor and then promoted to full professor in 1962 — an unusually fast track to that status. In 1965, he left for [[Stanford University]], moving again in 1990 to the [[University of California, Davis]], which had hired his wife, China historian [[Susan L. Mann]]. Skinner retired from teaching in 2005 but maintained an active research program until his death three years later.{{sfnp|Verdery|Smith|2009}} ==Research== Perhaps his best-known influence on Chinese Studies was his delineation of the [[Physiographic macroregions of China]].G.W. Skinner (ed.) (1977) "The City in Late Imperial China." ''[[Stanford University Press]]''.G.W. Skinner (1964–65). "Marketing and Social Structure in Rural China." Association for Asian Studies. [http://www.asian-studies.org/publications/cart/Members.aspx?Action=ServiceDetail&productID=407] In later years he was instrumental in the establishment of the China Historical Geographic Information Systems project at Harvard and [[Fudan]] Universities.[http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~chgis CHGIS Project] His papers and maps are archived in the library collections of Harvard, Cornell,[http://rmc.library.cornell.edu/ead/htmldocs/RMA02778.html Guide to the G. William Skinner Papers] the University of Washington,[http://content.lib.washington.edu/skinnerweb/ G.
